11121.content:
Heading into the candy store, decorated with bright colors all around and filled to the brim with a wide variety of sweets, you find yourself face-to-face with a kind hippo behind the counter. He's incredibly nice but incredibly fat - even for his species, often known for their heft, he sticks out like a sore thumb. Easily more than three times your width, the hippo is surprisingly delighted after you make your initial pitch. "I've been looking for a reason to move that cooler I bought to the front of the store, and offering some cold drinks will be a great way to make some money off of it!", he says.

Five minutes later, you've made the easiest sale of your life, and not a half bad one too. No matter how much of a jackass your boss tries to be, your next paycheck will be a bit heftier, guaranteed. As a token of goodwill, you agree to help the hippo move his cooler from the back room - it had been plugged in way in the back, still with some of the wrappers fastened - and slide it into place next to the cash register.

In thanks, the hippo catches you off-guard with one of the more generous offers you've heard in a while.

Have another, and maybe one more, on the way
111211.content:
Looking both ways and locking the front door, the hippo ushers you into a back room, where he unlocks a large safe. If the normal candy outside wasn't appetizing enough, this stuff is absolutely mouth-watering. It looks like every type of sweet you've ever loved is in there, and you catch yourself drooling a little bit by the time the hippo hands you a half-pound bag full of the stuff. He's been talking for a little while, and unfortunately while you were salivating you missed some of what he was saying.

"-so I wouldn't eat that much at one time, but it is what it is. Come by and see me tomorrow if you decide you like it, I'll get you some more."

You thank the kind hippo for the gift and leave, whistling a happy tune while you look at the bag. There's a little bit of everything in there - gummy bears, sour worms, chocolate pretzels, jellybeans and chocolate-covered raisins, just to name a few. After only a few steps down the road, you decide to try out one of the chocolate chews, just to see how good it could possibly be.

You toss it in your mouth, and MMM! It's one of the most delicious things you've ever tasted! The treat is sumptuous, just the right mix of chewy and melt-in-your-mouth. There's some caramel in the middle, just to make things even better. As you swallow, you feel strange for the slightest second, but the feeling is as jarring when it leaves a millisecond later. Unbenownst to you, you've gained about five pounds, but you're in good shape, so it's unnoticeable.

11131.content:
Your daydreaming stops suddenly when you notice someone angling to sit down on the park bench next to you. To your surprise, it's the massive kangaroo you saw just a few minutes ago... and he's about to sit on you. Scrambling out of the way, you manage to yelp out a quick "watch out!", delaying him just in time to prevent getting flattened. That said, he's still taking up most of the bench, and you're pressed against one of the rails.

"Oh my gosh, sorry about that, mister!" The roo looks deeply apologetic for his transgression. "Didn't mean you any harm - I didn't see you there!" You shake yourself off for a second and let him know it wasn't a big deal - no harm, no foul, right?

"Oh, but you must let me make it up to you somehow," he continues. "That's inexcusably rude of me to do. I know," he says, "we can dip into my business for a second, and I'll give you a discount to make up for almost squishing you. Unless you have somewhere to be." Gesturing at your work clothes, he assumes you're heading into work.

"Well, actually, about that," you nervously stammer, "I actually just got fired not five minutes ago, so my day's a bit more free than I expected it to be."

"Fantastic!", the kangaroo replies. "Follow me, it's just about half a block down this way. We just opened last week." If he feels that badly about almost sitting on you, you figure he might make it worth your time, so you walk behind him. Just a minute later, you've arrived at...
11131.title: Someone sits down on the bench next to you.

choices: The job search doesn't go so well
111312.content:
Taking up multiple storefronts on the next block is a huge restaurant, the neon sign above the windows reading "Jake's All You Can Eat." The place is massive - you can see seats wrapped around the whole perimeter, with dozens of food stations arranged throughout the building.

"Wow, this place looks incredible," you offer to the roo, not sure what to say.

"Thanks!", Jake replies, beaming. "It's my pride and joy, just opened it up and we're already seeing great business." To back up his statement, even though it's still breakfast time, you can see plenty of furs scattered throughout the place enjoying their meals.

Over the next fifteen minutes, the kangaroo gives you a walk-around tour of the place. Turns out he was a culinary school graduate who couldn't decide what he wanted to specialize in, so he didn't. Instead, he tried to develop recipes for every single cuisine he liked and stuck them all in one place. The bathrooms are spotless, the tables and chairs beautiful, and the food smells heavenly. By the time he finishes walking you around, you're already a fan, and you haven't even tried the food yet.

As the tour winds down, Jake asks you what you plan to do about your job. To be honest, you reply, you have no idea. You hate your old job, so you won't be fighting to get it back, but your skills aren't exactly up to par in the market. It might take a while for you to land your next opportunity.

"Ever tried sumo?", the kangaroo replies. You laugh at what seems like a jokey statement, but he's serious. "No, really, I have a bunch of friends who are into it. This city has a decent sumo scene. Good pay for anyone who can win the occasional round, too."

You stare at him in disbelief. "No offense, sir," you reply, "but I'm not exactly the sumo figure," pointing at your slim physique.

"Well, that's certainly true," Jake says. "Still, it's an option if you're struggling in the future. You'd have to put on some pounds, but it seems like a fun pastime. Some of them are even making it a career."

You thank him for the advice, and though you agree it might be fun, it's not exactly high on your list right now.

"Oh! By the way, I still need to apologize, yet again, for what happened earlier," Jake adds. You try to tell him he's been kind enough, but he replies that he's only more convinced by your respect. He goes behind the hostess station and comes back with a card in hand. "Friends of mine eat free here, no matter what," he tells you, handing you a lifetime card good for free meals whenever you want. You thank him profusely - if nothing else, you won't need to worry about paying for food for a while. Jake wishes you well as you leave, waving goodbye before you set your mind on sending out applications.

1113121.content:
Though you start pounding the pavement that afternoon, following up any leads you can find as to new work, things don't seem to be going so great. You can't tell if your old boss has a vendetta against you, as many of the places you apply don't seem to give you the time of day. In the few cases when you do land interviews, fate intervenes - on one day, a sudden pouring rain sends you into the interview soaking wet, to which the hiring manager weasel immediately dismisses you and calls the janitor to bring a mop, while on another, your briefcase pops open just as a gust of wind kicks up, blowing copies of your resume all around the city and leaving you wholly unprepared once you get into the interviewing room.

Luckily, you've got a decent-sized fallback fund to lean on - it'll help you pay rent for a while, as long as you don't make any extravagant purchases. To help save money, you start making healthy use of Jake's all-you-can-eat gift card as well.

In the first few days, you're eating normal, healthy meals as you come in, trying one dish each meal. They're all superb, to boot. But as the days turn into weeks, you find yourself becoming a bit depressed by the job search grind. After your first blown interview, you find yourself drowning your sorrows in a big three-course meal, washing down a steak and fried chicken with a heaping pile of pasta. The next day, after sending out a few resumes, you wander down and daydream while you eat, only stopping when your aching stomach cries mercy. Only then do you realize how much you ate - four empty plates of Chinese food and a big bowl of ice cream all went down before you even realized it.

Over the first month of eating at Jake's, you don't really notice any changes - maybe some of your smaller shirts don't reach down as far as they should, or your khakis are feeling a little tight. It's the second month of no callbacks that really hurts you, though. Some days you send out a dozen resumes and hear nothing, ending the day with a half-dozen tacos and a plate of cookies. Others, you struggle to even face the rejection, content to simply meander down to Jake's after sleeping late and spending the whole day there, intermittently stuffing your face and reading a magazine. This is when you really start looking different. Your belly, once nonexistent, is slowly swelling outward both in width and length. That same effect is repeating itself all over your body, with your arms growing thicker, your legs and butt expanding outward and a second chin slowly forming on your neck.
1113121.title: The job search doesn't go so well

You had always prided yourself on being a lithe, slim fox, never really going over 150 pounds. But for the first time ever, you've got a prominent gut that stretches out any and every shirt you try to wear. Your pants still come on, but they're almost skin-tight - you've often been relying on oversized t-shirts, large sweatshirts and stretchy sweatpants when you leave the house. If you ever hear back from any employers, you'll definitely need to replace your wardrobe a bit, too. Your dress shirts won't button up all the way, and your jacket is noticeably small all over.

Still, though, Jack's kindness has been wonderful, and you can't exactly spend good money from your savings on other food when a free option is sitting right in front of you. You've still got a few months of rent and living expenses saved up. It would be really, really nice if you could start bringing in at least a little bit of cash, though. Sifting through the classifieds at the restaurant at the start of your third month of searching, you suddenly see something that piques your interest.

111312112.title: Sumo... and it pays well. Really well.

1113121122.content:
So you're about 32 pounds away from the minimum standards this sumo league expects. While you could send them that email, they might turn you away without thinking about it if you're below their weight limits. Plus, even if they'd let you in, you'd get pushed around by the other wrestlers. To boot, you've got free unlimited access to an all-you-can eat buffet. That seems like a really simple solution to the issue.

Not wasting any time, you pull on your loosest sweatshirt and sweatpants and immediately head down to Jake's. Once you're there, you fill up your first plate to its limits with every fattening thing you can think of - fried chicken, a pile of fries, heavy pasta, gravy, fried rice and pizza - until it's a second away from spilling all over the floor. Once you're done, you find the nearest seat and absolutely tear into it. Bite after bite, gulp after gulp, you manage to choke it down in just a few minutes, at which point you repeat the process. Once you get to your fourth plate, you can start to feel your stomach getting full, but you push on until you finish the whole thing. Nursing your swollen, distended belly, you slowly walk over to the ice cream machine and make yourself a big bowl as well. Bringing it back to your seat, you let it melt over the course of a half-hour, rubbing your stomach to make it feel better. Once you think you have the room, the ice cream follows the rest of the food down your gullet, and with a huge burp, you finish your meal. Slowly, you struggle back to your apartment, where you immediately lay down and take a nap for a few hours.

Once you wake up, you've digested your huge meal, and your empty stomach calls out for food. Grinning at your gluttony, you head back down to Jake's and repeat the process as best you can, and soon it becomes a routine. A huge breakfast of bacon, eggs, huge pancakes and as many pastries you can grab is followed by a massive lunch, with a huge dinner following. You keep this diet up for a week, then hop back on the scale...
1113121122.title: Get to 225 pounds!

11131211221.content:
After a week of massive marathons of ridiculous meals, you weigh yourself, hoping you're well on your way to starting as a sumo. The scale tells you you're about halfway there, and it shows. The fluffy fur of your white belly has grown in a small but noticeable way, and your entire body seems to have thickened. Likewise, your sweats fit just a bit tighter than they did last week, though you've got plenty of room left for growth. Seeing the scale feels different - your chin pressed down on its double, and you have to poke your head out a little to see the number - but you're not as big as you hope. 207 means you've got plenty of eating left to do.

So you get to it as soon as you leave your apartment. Your first stop is at the ice cream dispenser, filling up a few bowls of ice cream. Then you fill plenty of glasses full of the sugariest sodas on Jake's tap. By the time you manage to grab four plates of food, the ice cream's half-melted, and between plates you drink it down like its milk. Your stomach's a bit bigger than it was last week, which lets you get an extra few minutes of stuffing your face before you're full, which gives you time to finish a bunch of plates of everything you can think of, plus the ice cream and soda. By the time your stomach finally begs for you to stop, it's largely round and distended, and you barely make it home before the food coma hits you.

You decide to eat as much as you can in the next week, not bothering to stop when you hit 225. Every morning you wake up and feel yourself be a little bit heavier. By the fifth day, you need to get a new set of sweats one size up, as your belly's starting to hang out of the waistband, and your legs and arms have swollen to make it feel a little tight. You even get a second set two sizes up in case you eventually need it. By this time your body is used to its daily marathon of calories, and whenever you're not eating, it wants you to eat. That's why you start eating four meals a day at Jake's instead of three. By the end of the week, you can comfortably eat nonstop for the better part of an hour, enjoying every bite. You finally bring yourself to weigh yourself by the end of the week to find you weight...

Oh, wow. You weren't expecting to see that big of a leap in your weight, but then again, you were already gaining two pounds a day. Add a few extra thousand calories per day, and it only makes sense that you had gained 40 pounds in the last week. It's really starting to show, too. When you breathe out, your gut hangs out inches over your waistline, and the rest of you feels so... thick. It's clear that you're much wider than you're used to being. Your replacement sweats are even starting to stretch a little bit.

More importantly, you're now a big enough furry to email the sumo league. You shoot them a quick email with your resume and send it in, then head down to Jake's for a relatively small meal, stopping after your third plate of food. By the time you're finished and get home, you have a response in your inbox. What does it say?
111312112212.title: 250 pounds (40 pounds heavier)

Get up to 275 and get in the ring ASAP!
1113121122122.content:

The representative from the sumo league apologizes, but has to turn you away as the league is already overbooked for wrestlers between 225 and 275 pounds. You're depressed when you read this, until a thought crosses through your mind. You respond to the email, asking about the specific enrollment numbers in the academy as a whole.

Luckily, the representative is more than happy to respond. The entry-level weight class, 225-275, holds 20 people with a waitlist of 10. Meanwhile, the 275-300 weight class has eight of 10 signups, and the figures drop from there for every respective step up in size from there.

The next few days are dedicated, much like the ones before them, to a nonstop regimen of stuffing yourself silly, and the effects are becoming more obvious every day. At this point, you're close to being able to eat nonstop for an hour, and the thousands of more calories you can squeeze in each sitting quickly show their effects. Your belly's growing outward, your arms and legs feel thicker every day, and you're clearly up to at least a third chin, with a fourth on the way. Each bite, it seems, is getting you in character to become a sumo wrestler.

A few days later, you're close to 275 pounds, but a thought strikes you. Do you want to start at 275 and see how things go, or push up to 300 pounds - double your starting weight - before you start wrestling?

The next, your gut has officially started moving downward as well as outward, weighing itself down. From what you can see of your legs, they're enormously flabby, the size of tree trunks.

The realization of just how big you've gotten sweeps over you in a wave, and you're suddenly very disappointed in yourself. And the disappointment spurs your appetite as well. Your next step is...

111312121.content:
Sheepishly, you try to draw as little attention to yourself as possible as you leave the buffet and head to the nearest store with clothing. About a block away, you find what appears to be a large, extensive clothing store and go inside. Before you do anything else, you look at yourself in the mirror, and you're stunned at what you see. Your job-search funk had made you disregard your appearance and then some. Your belly strains at your too-small sweatshirt, pushing out in every direction. Your reaction is to head directly to the plus-size section, as you're not exactly able to wear mediums and larges anymore.

The plus-size section is surprisingly extensive, which you didn't quite expect. The typical XLs and 2XLs are there, but that's not all. Everything from jeans to dress shirts are well above your current size, as big as you already are, rising as large as 12XLs, which look closer to tents than clothing for the average fur. You grab an XL and a 2XL so you can better compare what you need right now, and for kicks, you grab a 12XL to see just how foolishly large it looks on you.

After picking out your clothing, you wander over to the store's changing rooms. There's a clerk there waiting to check you in, just to make sure you're not going to walk out wearing the merchandise.
